column1: Speech recognition applications include voice user interfaces such as voice dialing (e.g. "call home")
column2: call routing (e.g. "I would like to make a collect call")
column4: search key words (e.g. find a podcast where particular words were spoken)
column7: preparation of structured documents (e.g. a radiology report)
column11: and aircraft (usually termed direct voice input).The term voice recognition or speaker identification refers to identifying the speaker
column12: rather than what they are saying. Recognizing the speaker can simplify the task of translating speech in systems that have been trained on a specific person's voice or it can be used to authenticate or verify the identity of a speaker as part of a security process.From the technology perspective
column13: speech recognition has a long history with several waves of major innovations. Most recently
column14: the field has benefited from advances in deep learning and big data. The advances are evidenced not only by the surge of academic papers published in the field
column15: but more importantly by the worldwide industry adoption of a variety of deep learning methods in designing and deploying speech recognition systems.
